unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Why Film Festivals Are More Than Just Red Carpets
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, Festival! Why Film Festivals Are More Than Just Red Carpets

unnormalised: Hey cinephiles! Ever wondered what goes on beyond the glitz and glamour of those fancy red carpets? We're talking film festivals, yaar! They're so much more than just a showcase for Bollywood stars and Hollywood bigwigs.
normalised: Hey cinephiles! Ever wondered what goes on beyond the glitz and glamour of those fancy red carpets? We are talking film festivals, yaar! They are so much more than just a showcase for Bollywood stars and Hollywood bigwigs.

unnormalised: Think of film festivals as the ultimate celebration of cinema. They're a melting pot of creativity, bringing together filmmakers, actors, critics, and passionate movie buffs from all corners of the globe. Whether it's the prestigious International Film Festival of India (IFFI) held annually in Goa, or smaller, independent fests tucked away in cities like Pune or Kolkata, each offers a unique window into the world of storytelling.
normalised: Think of film festivals as the ultimate celebration of cinema. Whether it is the prestigious International Film Festival of India (I F F I) held annually in Goa, or smaller, independent fests tucked away in cities like Pune or Kolkata, each offers a unique window into the world of storytelling.

unnormalised: But why should you care? Well, for starters, you get to see films you wouldn't normally find in your local multiplex. We're talking thought-provoking documentaries, experimental shorts, and feature films from countries you might not even know exist! Remember that critically acclaimed film, "Gully Boy"? It gained major buzz after premiering at the Berlin International Film Festival. Festivals can be game changers!

unnormalised: Beyond the screenings, film festivals are a fantastic place to network and learn. You can attend workshops, Q&A sessions with directors, and panel discussions on everything from scriptwriting to cinematography. Imagine getting to hear Anurag Kashyap share his insights on filmmaking – pretty cool, right?

unnormalised: And let's not forget the atmosphere! Picture yourself surrounded by like-minded individuals, debating the merits of the latest Iranian art film over a cup of chai. It's an immersive experience that truly deepens your appreciation for the art of cinema.

unnormalised: So, next time you're looking for something different to do, check out a film festival near you. You might just discover your next favorite filmmaker or find a new perspective on the world. Who knows, you might even spot Shah Rukh Khan! Maybe at the Mumbai Film Festival, held annually around October or November at locations around 20 km from my home. Trust me, it's an experience worth the ticket price of Rs. 500 (or more, depending on the pass). And yeah, I'm hoping to see some great movies there this year. Go for it, people! Support good cinema!
